sentence.text: She had been macrosomic (birth weight of 2.2 kg at 30 weeks of gestation) and generalized hypertrichosis was present at birth and remained prominent.
A patent ductus arteriosus was ligated on day 17 of life.
She developed pulmonary hypertension of unknown cause and this was a significant problem in the second year of life.
This appeared to be steroid-responsive and gradually improved in the third year of life when steroid therapy was discontinued.
A lung biopsy showed normal histology.
At age 4 years she developed communicating hydrocephalus treated with a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt.
Her subsequent clinical course was dominated by respiratory disease.
She had recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections and at age 7 years presented with hemoptysis.
Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) demonstrated multiple tortuous arteriovenous communications in both lungs (Fig. 6).
A number of these were thorascopically ligated.
However, she continued to have recurrent hemoptysis over the next 12 months, until at the age of 8, she was found to be IgG deficient.
IgA and IgM levels were normal.

Although the levels were only mildly low, a decision was made to commence monthly intravenous immunoglobulin infusions at 0.4 g/kg with marked improvement in her condition, improved growth, and cessation of recurrent respiratory infections.
When the infusions were reduced to every other month, she started having recurrent respiratory infections and her FEV1 dropped from 90% to 70% of predicted.
